Award.AwardTitle: CCLI: The Geoscience Student Data Network: A Cyberinfrastructure-Based Approach For Collaborative Classroom-, Field-, and Laboratory-Based Undergraduate Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is developing a software application with social networking capabilities known as the Geoscience Student Data Network (GSDNet) that is being created in partnership with the National Geothermal Data System. GSDNet is enabling students to work in a single cyberenvironment where they are collaboratively and collectively contributing, accessing, manipulating, and analyzing data. GSDNet is also facilitating classroom instruction related to data management and modeling of earth processes via the integration of data layers and student-peer collaborations. The tool is being tested within a curriculum offered in parallel at City College of New York, a large minority-serving urban institution, and Boise State University. The project is developing three courses and supporting lab and field activities related to the applied research theme of geothermal energy. The project is exposing students from both institutions to field studies of geothermal systems and subsequently is requiring the two student populations to exchange ideas, information and data both in the field and in the classroom using the GDSNet cyberinfrastructure. The project is testing the efficacy of this approach, and also is assessing whether student communication skills involving writing and communication are improved via the use of GSDNet. Moreover, the project is determining how students from different socio-economic and cultural backgrounds interact in the field and via the associated cyberinfrastructure. The field investigations are leading to individual senior thesis or independent study projects that are resulting in student research presentations at local and national conferences. The project is employing an iterative formative evaluation that is helping to improve the courses and the GSDNet in addition to a summative evaluation that is assessing the short- and long-term impacts of the curriculum and associated cybertools on student learning and performance. The PI and Senior Personnel are presenting the results of the program at conferences and through peer-reviewed publications. In addition, a series of webinar modules are being produced to raise awareness and provide training on the use of the GSDNet to the larger geosciences community. Summarily, the project focuses on developing and implementing cybertools and curricula that are better preparing students from diverse backgrounds for successful careers and graduate studies in the geosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Geoscience Student Data Network (GSDNet) project developed a virtual environment that facilitates student collaboration and data analysis. The GSDNet learning model created a 3-course curriculum to train future workforce geoscientists in data collection, data mining, documentation of metadata, manipulation, and visualization. The geothermal-themed curriculum devised to accompany collaborative learning leverages resources from DOE- and NSF-funded cyberinfrastructure projects and utilizes successful and sustainable commercial platforms to overcome barriers to adoption (e.g., Google Drive, ArcGIS Explorer Online, Dropbox). The key course revised through the award, EAS 308: Modeling/Databases, has been run for three semesters in its revised form. The course is now offered yearly and is the keystone course for training students in data management and analysis. The course has received significant enhancements in handling a variety of earth science datasets, statistical treatment, and visualization. Furthermore, the course now has a cyberinfrastructure exploration component where students claim ownership of a particular database (EPA, NGDC, EarthChem) and present to their peers the relevance of the data to geoscience research as well as the formats and idiosyncrasies of its inherent data format.

In addition to the Modeling/Databases course, a Geothermal Resource course offered jointly at CCNY and Boise State prepared students for field data collection and research projects and to collect information for development of the GSDNet learning model. Students at both institutions exhibited discomfort with hypothesis building and testing using mathematical methods. This is partly due to non-uniform mathematics background among all students. Additionally, most students receive their mathematics instruction outside of the context of the earth sciences and therefore have trouble recognizing which tools to apply to a particular problem. Therefore, in the following iteration of the course (Fall 2013) the PI integrated more statistics and data processing and analysis exercises into the Modeling/Databases course to promote the use of quantitative techniques in the context of earth sciences. This modification has been permanently adopted by the department, and is now in its fifth iteration. The course has been led by three different instructors, who have shared and reused the materials developed during the award period.

We faced challenges of having inadequate digital infrastructure to execute a course simultaneously at Boise State and CCNY, resulting in an impediment and distraction that may adversely affect students. As a result, we abandoned the joint collaboration between the two institutions during classroom work in favor of collaboration in the field and collaboration within each classroom, particularly in preparation for the geothermal field trip in Year 2. The project enabled identification of specific problems with digital infrastructure, which are currently being addressed by the institution as a result of securing follow-on funding by the PI and CCNY colleagues.

For the field capstone course, students worked individually and in collaboration to generate data to assess the prospectability of a geothermal field in south central Idaho using water chemistry, surface hydrology, faults, clay and zeolite mineralogy of field samples, surface temperature of springs, ASTER images, VIS-NIR spectral reflectance of surface sediment. Relevant datasets for case studies and field project were sourced from the following public data repositories and databases: Nevada Bureau of Mines and Geology, USGS GIS Data; NASA Aster Library; Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance (IEDA), American Mineralogist Crystal Structure Database as well as extracted from DOE publications, BLM reports, and peer-reviewed literature.
